This is the Global News Podcast from the BBC World Service.
I'm Nick Miles, and in the early hours of Monday the 17th of June, these are our main stories.
A peace summit on Ukraine has closed with the reaffirmation of the country's territorial integrity,
but some attending nations who've maintained close ties with Moscow didn't sign the communicate.
A jihadist group has claimed it killed dozens of soldiers in an attack in Burkina Faso this month,
which the military authorities haven't acknowledged. Another tourist has been founded in Greece,

Also in this podcast, we head to Scotland.

Where we meet the hoof tremor, who's become a surprise internet star.
If there were any doubts about whether Ukraine would be giving up territory in the hope of peace,
those doubts seemed to have been put to rest. It was something that had been suggested by Russia,
but at the end of a peace summit in Switzerland, world leaders have ruled out expecting Ukraine
to surrender land. Ursula Fondeline is the European Commission president.
I call on Russia to heed the message of the international community,
respect the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine,
put an end to imperialist violence and bring back the children.
But speaking at the same news conference, Ukraine's president, Volodomir Zelensky,
said achieving swift peace was a priority.
We are at a war and we don't have time for prolonged work. Moving to peace means acting fast.
Preparations will take months, not years. So when the action plans for peace are ready
and when every step is worked out, the path will be open for the second peace summit and thus
for ending this war for a just and lasting peace.
I asked Sarah Rainesford, who was out the summit, just how successful it had been.
Well, according to Mrs Zelensky, very successful. He called it a great success.
He stressed that 84 countries who had delegations here joined a joint communique, which underlined
Ukraine's right to essentially not to be invaded and called for things such as an
increase in prisoner exchanges, called for nuclear security, called for food security,
all issues that the delegations here could talk about, could discuss and could essentially
agree upon. But there were a handful of countries including Saudi Arabia, India,
Mexico, who didn't sign up to that final communique. And of course, the big missing part in all of
this was not only Russia, but it's big back of China who shunned these talks, essentially after
pressure from Moscow. So I think this is an important first step, certainly,
Ukraine and its Western backers and now other countries are trying to move towards a possible
path of peace. Ukraine sees in the initiative on that, but it is going to be a long and very
complex path. And Russia, of course, is still prosecuting its war.
Yeah, indeed. And the Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov has said, look, we're open for peace
and as far as Ukraine is concerned, the conditions for them will get worse as time goes on.
What's going to change if anything between now and this second peace summit, do you think,
to make things better for Ukraine? Well, I think it's important to say, first of all,
that Russia is saying it's open for peace, but in fact, it's calling for the full capitulation
of Ukraine. So when Vladimir Putin talks about a peace proposal, what he's actually saying is
withdraw from your own territory, Ukraine. So I think it's quite clear that Kiev has dismissed
those suggestions as absurd. And that's why Ukraine, I think, is trying to push its own initiative
and trying to get the broadest possible international alliance behind it. So it's going to be a working
progress. They are aiming for a second leaders summit where Russia could be brought to the same
table. And I think that's a fair old way off at the moment. We're nowhere near that.
It's air obviously keeping America on board is key to success for Ukraine. It's going to be very
difficult, isn't it? Because come November, it could be Mr Trump in the White House, and that
will paint a very different picture for Ukraine. Potentially, yeah. I mean, of course, Donald
Trump has said he if he were to return to the presidency, he'd end this war in 24 hours.
What that means, nobody really knows. There's so much uncertainty. And I think that is the
important context for what's happening here. But certainly at this point, America is still
supporting Ukraine militarily, although Mr Zelensky talked about that today and talked about the fact

He says, you know, Ukraine is committed to still fighting on the battlefield, but this is a parallel

Video footage posted on social media shows last Tuesday's raid on the town of Mansila

There are reports that many civilians are missing following the attack. I heard more from our
Africa editor, Will Ross. Well, the video posted by the al-Qaeda-linked JNIM group shows a large

It also is confirming or saying that it was behind this raid, and there have in recent days

but it is relentless shooting and we understand that that is also footage taken from Mansila,
although that's yet to be confirmed. Some civilians in the area have talked about a lot of people

Will you mention the JNIM group? What do we know about that group and the impact they're having on

Now, will the generals are in charge at the most of the military government? They

but that doesn't seem to be working, does it? Yeah, I mean, the security situation is pretty

Netanyahu has described the introduction of daily tactical pauses in military activity in
part of southern Gaza as unacceptable. The move intended to allow more aid to reach the strip
was announced by the Israeli military earlier on Sunday. The army is said to have reassured
Mr Netanyahu that the 11-hour daytime pauses between 8am and 7pm every day only apply to the
road that leads northwards from the Karim Shalom crossing and that fighting in Rafa would
continue. Well, the Prime Minister has come under strong pressure from far-right members of his
coalition government to reject any pauses in the conflict until Hamas is totally defeated.
I spoke to our correspondent John Donelson in Jerusalem and started by asking him what exactly
do we know about this IDF announcement on Sunday? Well, certainly we've been getting pretty mixed
messages from both the Israeli military and the Israeli government today. It started this morning
with an announcement from the IDF that they were going to be introducing a daily tactical military
pause to allow more aid in through the Karim Shalom crossing from Israel into Gaza, which is right
in the south of the Gaza Strip, very close to Rafa. However, very quickly, we then had comments from
Israel's hard-line right-wing national security minister, it's Omar Ben-Gavir,
saying that anyone who'd made that sort of decision was both evil and a fool and within
an hour or so we then had a clarifying statement from the IDF saying that there would be no cessation
of violence in Rafa or in southern Gaza. So it's pretty difficult to see whether there's going to
be any sort of change on the ground. We're going to have to wait and see Israel's Prime Minister
Benjamin Netanyahu has said this evening that any sort of tactical pause in hostilities is unacceptable.
We've spoken to the United Nations. They say they cautiously welcome the move, but they want to see
whether it really has any effect on the ground. And I think it's an indication really of the discord
between the Israeli military and some of the Israeli government. And John, given what you know
about the geography of that part of Gaza, if there was some kind of tactical military pause,
what difference might it make to the amount of aid that gets in? Karim Shalom crossing is very,
very close to Rafa where Israel is focusing its military operation at the moment. So there is a
road that goes in. It joins up with the Salah al-Din road which runs north to south in Gaza and
it's the main road along the coast that allows people to access northern Gaza. So I guess if there was
a decrease in hostilities specifically on that road, it might allow aid agencies to operate
more freely, but there's no sign that Israel's military operation in Rafa is stopping. So we're
just going to have to wait and see. What Israel says is that it is allowing a substantial number
of trucks into Gaza every day, some 200 trucks, but there is a problem with them being picked up
on the other side by the aid agencies and then distributed around Gaza. And that's because the
aid agencies say it's simply too dangerous. John Donenson. Well, as we just heard, fighting is
expected to continue around the city of Rafa in Gaza south. It's where Israel says Hamas's last
major stronghold is based, but also where large numbers of displaced Palestinians are still
sheltering. UNICEF's James Elder is now in Rafa. He spoke to the BBC's Lee's Deset.
No one should be surprised at how much worse things have got. Of course, when there is a
relentless bombardment and aid restrictions and denials and now the heat. We shouldn't be surprised,
but we should be woefully alarmed. So I think for me, Lee's to come back and see scenes in hospitals
of walking over children on on floor with missing limbs and with grave head injuries and not yet
getting the care they need because doctors are utterly swamp. It felt like the first month of the war,
the war again. So I think that that has certainly been a startling sense amid what is
worryingly becoming almost a normalization of this, a normalization of the of the attacks of the
carnage of the children living in in constant fear. As you may have been hearing this confusion
this morning about whether or not the Israeli military is going to have what they call the
tactical pause, it does seem that there may be a decision to allow for calm along the key corridor
and the Salahuddin road toward the Kerem Shalom crossing to allow the trucks to move unhindered.
If that is the case, would that help much? Look, in one sense, in the most simple sense,
I think any pause, less in bombardments is good for children. Here, where I'm in Rafa and
the board of Khan Unis, the last three nights have been relentless. I thought I knew what the
sound of nearby bombardments was. I had no idea. It's like someone beating pots and pans next to
your head. So beyond the obvious, obvious physical threat to children is just the psychological
sense, the impossibility of sleeping. And if it's not that, it's drones. It's a lawnmower above your
head. Now that's, I'm talking about a couple of nights. We're talking about 250 nights. Any pause
in bombardments is good. And we need much better conditions to bring aid in and to safely
deliver that aid inside the Gaza Strip. So we need enhanced security and improved access. And
remembering these aren't pine the sky ideas, Israel as the occupying power has a legal responsibility
to facilitate on the ground to ensure that it's not as chaotic as we're now finding it.
So we need that safety. We need more aid. And as we've been saying for months and months,
we need more entry routes to come in. That was James Elder.
An Iranian convicted in Sweden of war crimes has been freed as part of a prisoner swap between the
two countries. Hamid Nouri, who was serving a life sentence, has returned to Tehran in exchange for
the Swedish diplomat, Johann Flotherus, and the dual national Said Azizi, who arrived home in
Stockholm late on Saturday. Iran has often been accused of hostage diplomacy. There have been
other exchanges of dual nationals and foreigners in Tehran for Iranians jailed abroad, as well as
other concessions sought by Tehran. Well, his dissent spoke to the BBC Persian correspondent
Sivash Adalem, and asked him first for more on Hamid Nouri. Hamid Nouri was the assistant
of the deputy prosecutor if Iran back in the 80s. This was a time of war and political turmoil
inside the country. He had been accused of being involved in the mass killing of political prisoners
in 1987. It was a very bloody episode in Iranian history. Resonates very strongly with Iranian
expatriates. So they were always trying to find a way to either get him or anyone else who was
involved in those killings, particularly Abraham Raisi, the former president of Iran, who recently
died in a helicopter crash, somehow to be held accountable in some sort of international forum.
So when he traveled to Sweden, when they lured him to Sweden, and the Swedish police arrested
him and they put him on trial, they felt like they had their day. And it took weeks and weeks of
testimonies, which brought some measure of closure for the victims, and Hamid Nouri himself was there
trying to defend his actions. And what about the Swedish diplomat, Johann Flotherus,
site as easy? Any evidence that they were indeed as Iran can charge them with spying?
Well, if there is any evidence, none was presented because all these cases are held behind closed
doors. And we really don't know what Iran's evidence where hostage diplomacy is something that
Iran has been known to be involved in. It's part of its playbook. A lot of people, dual nationals,
dozens of them are languishing in Iranian jails are being held as bargaining chips. So this
seemed to be the latest case in that episode. And one was left behind. Any more details about
what was the discussions around this and why this one happened and another didn't? Well, there are
five Swedish nationals who are being held in Iran. Two were swapped with this. And that has
become the focus of a lot of criticism by the Swedish media, why just these two? And not one of the
most high profile cases, which is Ahmad Rezogjall Ali, another dual citizen who had been arrested
seven years ago on charges of espionage. And his been convicted and has received a death sentence.
So his on a death row, his family weren't informed. And a lot of people are asking, well, he was the
most high profile case. And he was on a death row. Why wasn't he part of that prisoner swap to which the
Swedish prime minister replied that the Iranians refused to even consider his case.
Al Sivash Adaland from BBC Persian. Now, if watching the news programme showing conflict,
or even the football matches in the European championships is going to be too stressful,
how about tuning into a very different type of content? One man in Scotland has built up a huge

washing, the internet is full of oddly satisfying content. And for one man in Scotland posting
up close and personal videos of his job is earning him up to 170 million views a month.
Welcome to the hoof GP and I count with an extremely sore back left foot that becomes very obvious
after the very first swipe of the grinder. Graham Parker, otherwise known as the hoof GP,
is a professional hoof trimmer working across cattle farms in the area. From pusplats to huge
ulcers, no effort is spared when it comes to relieving animals of their sore and clogged feet.
Starting off five years ago, as a way to share his technique with local farmers,
his audience rapidly grew with subscribers both in and outside the industry.
Every single day of the week people are contacting us to ask how to do this or how to do that,
how we can help them or just to say how we've kind of helped them in their lives, even although
they're not in agriculture, which is something I never expected to happen but has been really
humbling and incredibly kind of endearing thing that has happened. From the audience's reaction,
it seems to be a mix of fascination with his craft and his care for animals that keeps them
watching. One YouTube user said, if you would have told me three weeks ago that watching cows
get their hooves repaired would make my life better, I would have laughed in your face. Well,
here we are today and I love it. Others have reported looking more closely at cows and fields on their
commutes to work or just to growth in their general compassion for animals, all thanks to his videos.
And for some, they've even found transferable skills and grains content. One user commented,
strangely, I find myself peeling potatoes differently now.
But despite the fame and 6.8 million subscribers across the social media platforms,
it's still just a side hustle to his one true passion. Things have got quite big but I'm still

Sasha Slichter was staying with extreme weather and Sunday was another hot day in a large

soaring into the 90 degrees Fahrenheit and higher, that's above 32 degrees Celsius.
It's called a heat dome, a massive high pressure system, which is expected to build over the

heat kills more than twice as many people each year on average as hurricanes and tornadoes combined.
Lees DeSett heard more from Jolene Russell, a professor of geosciences at the University of

We are on our 18th day of temperatures above 100 degrees Fahrenheit, 38 degrees Celsius.
It means that we're walking our dogs at five in the morning because otherwise they burn
their feet. It means we have to get our kids outside to play or to ride their bikes early in
the morning or late in the evening because the only time it's safe is when the sun's not up.
Explain to us what the difference is between intense heat and a heat dome.
Well, a heat wave, our National Weather Service here in the US, defines it as a period of unusually
hot weather that typically lasts two days or more. But a heat dome is a big, stagnant, high pressure
system. I think several states wide, hundreds of kilometers in the upper parts of the atmosphere
that allows heat to build underneath over multiple days is created when the jet stream, which we
share with you in the UK, you guys are rainy and gray. I understand my parents who live in
northern Montana right on the Canadian border are also rainy and gray because the jet stream is
overhead there. But what that's allowed to happen is an enormous dome, a very warm, very dry air
has been sitting over the southwest of the United States for 18 days. It's now starting to move
towards our Midwest and into the East and our Great Lakes area. And they are going to be suffering
some spectacularly high temperatures for them. And I understand that in some areas they're
different. Some are dry, which I understand is the case in Arizona, and some are humid. Yes, as we
move towards Texas near the Gulf of Mexico, you have incredibly humid air stretching all the way
from the Gulf of Mexico up to our Great Lakes on the Canadian border. And all of that humidity
actually puts more pressure on people. It means that not only are the temperatures hotter than
